takesSectionVOList.title: Rationale for Vehicle Entry Permit Fees for Foreign-registered Cars
takesSectionVOList.content:
1 Mr Ang Wei Neng asked the Minister for Transport (a) what is the basis of increasing the Vehicle Entry Permit fees for foreign-registered cars from $20 to $35 per day and goods vehicles from $10 to $40 per calendar month; (b) what is the expected revenue increase arising from the increase in Vehicle Entry Permit fees; and (c) whether the Malaysian government has informed Singapore on their proposal to impose a fee on Singapore-registered vehicles entering Johor.

The Senior Minister of State for Transport (Mrs Josephine Teo) (for the Minister for Transport): Mdm Speaker, our Vehicle Entry Permit (VEP) fee and the Goods Vehicle Permit (GVP) fee seek to equalise the cost of owning and using a foreign-registered vehicle in Singapore, with that for a Singapore-registered vehicle. There is a need to do so, given the significantly higher costs for Singapore-registered vehicles because of our Certificate of Entitlement (COE) policy, higher vehicle taxes and so on. By way of background, the GVP has been in existence since the 1960s and the VEP since the 1970s.

LTA periodically reviews these fees to ensure that they continue to serve their objective. The cost difference between owning and using a foreign-registered vehicle and a Singapore-registered vehicle has widened in recent years. This is why we need to revise the fees. I should point out that this is the first increase in the VEP fee in 20 years, the last being in 1994. The VEP is not always adjusted upwards. In fact, it was reduced in 2004 for foreign-registered cars because COE prices had gone down during that period, resulting in lower overall costs for Singapore-registered cars. The GVP fee had remained unchanged since its introduction until the recent revision.

Buses, taxis and motorcycles are not affected by the recent increase in VEP and GVP fees. In addition, all foreign-registered cars and motorcycles continue to enjoy around 125 VEP-free days per year, on top of daily VEP-free hours which are from 5.00 pm to 2.00 am, and which is extended to 12.00 pm to 2.00 am during Singapore's mid-year and year-end school holidays. Effectively, based on 2013 data, only about one in 10 foreign-registered cars that enter Singapore will be affected by the recent increase in VEP fee.

The VEP is not intended as a revenue generator. The VEP fees collected vary, depending on the number of foreign-registered cars and motorcycles entering Singapore and their length of stay during VEP-chargeable hours.

On Malaysia's proposed entry fee on non-Malaysia-registered vehicles entering Johor, we have not been officially informed of it by the Malaysian government. We are concerned whether it is directed towards Singapore vehicles. We have contacted the Malaysian government to seek details and are awaiting their reply before deciding on our response. 

Mr Ang Wei Neng (Jurong): Mdm Speaker, I thank the Senior Minister of State for the comprehensive reply. We understand that the purpose of the VEP is to curb vehicle congestion during the peak hours and typically during the week days. Foreign-registered vehicles entering Singapore are given 10 VEP-free days per calendar year, besides not having to pay VEP during Saturdays, Sundays and public holidays. If the Malaysian authorities had decided to go ahead with their own VEP, would MOT consider negotiating with them so as to provide the same kind of number of fee-free days?

My second supplementary question is about the higher toll charges imposed by Malaysia at the Causeway since 1 August 2014. Both MOT and LTA have indicated the intention for Singapore to match the same. However, many Singaporeans are concerned about the impact of the higher toll charges. Would the Senior Minister of State provide an update on this issue?

Mrs Josephine Teo: As I had noted earlier in our response, we have not had official word from the Malaysian government on what they intend to do regarding the entry permit fees that reportedly they would like to levy. Until details are made known to us, it is premature to comment on it. So, I would suggest that we not say anything more at this point in time.

Regarding the Causeway tolls, there is a Parliamentary Question (PQ) following this first PQ that relates to the Causeway toll, so I suggest we take it together with Question No 2.

takesSectionVOList.title: Matching Toll Charges at Causeway and Second Link
takesSectionVOList.content:
2 Mr Pritam Singh asked the Minister for Transport whether LTA plans to review its long-standing policy of matching toll charges at the Causeway and Second Link to those set by Malaysia in future; and (b) whether a Whole-of-Government study has been carried out by Singapore to assess the prospect of higher toll charges on Singapore businesses operating in the Iskandar zone in Johor.

The Senior Minister of State for Transport (Mrs Josephine Teo) (for the Minister for Transport): Mdm Speaker, toll charges at the Causeway and Second Link were introduced by Malaysia in 1998. Our matching policy reflects the shared nature of the two crossings, and ensures a fair distribution of total revenues from the crossings. Without a matching policy, lower toll charges by one side may simply be offset by higher tolls levied by the other side. There is no assurance that toll charges foregone by one side will be translated into lower total charges which benefit motorists.

Hence, in response to Malaysia's Causeway tolls revision on 1 August 2014, we have announced Singapore's intention to match Malaysia's new and increased toll charges in due course.

The Government has limited information on the cost structures and market conditions of Singapore businesses operating in the Iskandar zone in Johor. But clearly, there will be some impact on their costs.

In this regard, we note reports in the Malaysian media that the Malaysian authorities will review the tolls. Should Malaysia reduce or do away with the toll charges, Singapore will follow suit. This would be welcomed, I think, by both Singapore and Malaysia businesses on both sides of the Causeway. 

Mr Pritam Singh (Aljunied): Mdm Speaker, I would like to thank the Senior Minister of State for that very helpful clarification. I have three supplementary questions for the Senior Minister of State. First, did the Malaysian government forewarn Singapore of their intention to raise toll charges at the Causeway on 1 August, and have there been any joint discussions about this round of toll hikes since 1 August so as to manage costs for Singaporeans and Malaysians travelling to and fro both countries?

The second question is: did the Singapore Government inform its Malaysian counterparts when it planned to increase VEP charges in July this year, and if not, does it plan to do so going forward?

Finally, in view of the close relationship between Singapore and Malaysia, especially between the Prime Ministers in recent years, has the Government suggested to the Malaysian authorities to consider tagging the additional toll from 1 August along the Eastern Dispersal Link rather than at the Customs, Immigration and Quarantine (CIQ), so as not to penalise drivers who do not use the Eastern Dispersal Link and only travel into Johor Bahru city?

Mrs Josephine Teo: Mdm Speaker, the answer to the Member's first question is no. We were not informed in advance of Malaysia's intention to increase the tolls at the Causeway on 1 August. The answer to his second question is yes. We informed our Malaysian counterparts in advance why there is a need to revise the VEP fees. As I have explained in my answer to the earlier Parliamentary Question on VEP fees, it is really because the cost of owning a Singapore-registered vehicle and using it on Singapore roads has risen, whereas the similar cost for a foreign-registered vehicle had largely remained unchanged. And so, yes, our Malaysian counterparts were aware of the intention to raise our VEP fees.

We very much would like our Malaysian counterparts to come to the discussion table and look at what are the better ways of managing this issue of the Causeway tolls so as not to penalise drivers who do not use the Eastern Dispersal Link. Our long-standing policy is well known to our Malaysian counterparts, and that means if the Causeway tolls levied by the Malaysian side were to be reduced or removed, we would do likewise.

takesSectionVOList.title: Clinical Trials for Sanofi Dengue Vaccine
takesSectionVOList.content:
3 Mr Christopher de Souza asked the Minister for Health (a) whether there are clinical trial runs for the Sanofi dengue vaccine being conducted in Singapore; (b) whether an approved dengue vaccine can be used to help reduce the number of people who suffer from dengue fever in Singapore; and (c) whether the Ministry has plans to eventually make a dengue vaccine available under the National Childhood Immunisation Programme (NCIP), just like the polio vaccine.

The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health (Assoc Prof Dr Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim) (for the Minister for Health): Mdm Speaker, a Phase II clinical trial for the Sanofi dengue vaccine has been conducted among 1,200 patients in Singapore. It aims to assess the immune response and safety of the vaccine in healthy persons aged two to 45 years old. The study started in 2009 and follow-up of persons in the study is still on-going at our public hospitals.

A dengue vaccine could potentially help reduce the number of cases of dengue in Singapore. However, it is too early to definitively assess the effects of the Sanofi dengue vaccine. As with all new vaccines, it must first be scientifically assessed by the Health Sciences Authority (HSA) for its safety, quality and efficacy to meet internationally benchmarked standards, before the vaccine is approved for use in Singapore. In granting marketing approval, HSA will take into account whether the data provided from the clinical trial studies demonstrates that the benefits of the vaccine outweigh the risks of potential side effects, if any.

Results from two large scale Phase III studies, conducted in Asia and South America, were reported recently. Both studies focused on effectiveness of the vaccine in children, whereas in Singapore, most dengue cases occur in adults. The results were similar and showed lower efficacy against dengue virus serotypes 1 and 2, which are the commonest types circulating in Singapore. There had previously been reports that while past infection with one serotype confers immunity and protection against that serotype, it could lead to more serious disease if infection with a different serotype occurs.

More study is needed to ascertain whether similarly, incomplete protection from vaccination could potentially result in the risk of more severe infection from serotypes which the vaccine protects poorly against. To reduce the number of dengue cases, other measures such as reducing the number of mosquito breeding sites and using mosquito repellents continue to play an important part.

An Expert Committee on Immunisation (ECI) advises MOH on matters related to vaccination. The ECI considers factors such as the local burden of disease, vaccine safety, efficacy and cost-effectiveness when recommending whether a particular vaccine, such as the dengue vaccine when it becomes available, should be included into the National Childhood Immunisation Schedule.

takesSectionVOList.title: Special Parade Preview Shows for Singapore's 50th National Day in 2015
takesSectionVOList.content:
4 Mr Liang Eng Hwa asked the Minister for Defence in view of the celebration of Singapore's 50th National Day next year, whether the Government will consider having two NDP Preview shows so that more Singaporeans can have the opportunity to attend the parade at the Padang and celebrate this very significant National Day.

The Minister for Defence (Dr Ng Eng Hen): Mdm Speaker, MINDEF agrees with the Member of Parliament Mr Liang that it would be good, indeed ideal, if more Singaporeans could attend the NDP 2015 next year, in celebration of our 50th National Day.

The Organising Committee is evaluating various options to achieve this. The Member has asked about extra shows. Let me just give some details on our current format. There are now four shows open prior to the actual NDP – three National Education Shows for school students and the NDP Preview itself. The Member has suggested and asked if another NDP Preview would be one way of increasing the attendance. We can explore the idea but adding another NDP Preview may tax participants too heavily, who would require some rest before the actual NDP Show.

However, the Organising Committee is exploring other ideas to allow more Singaporeans to see the show "live", such as increasing the seating capacity at the Padang or creating satellite viewing platforms throughout the Marina Bay area during the Preview and NDP 2015. We are also working with the People's Association on activities to celebrate National Day in Heartland locations.

Mr Liang Eng Hwa (Holland-Bukit Timah): Madam, first and foremost, I want to congratulate the Defence Minister for yet another spectacular NDP this year. Increasingly, we are seeing more Singaporeans taking part in the celebration with great pride. And NDP, being a pinnacle celebration, I think, obviously is where more Singaporeans want to be a part of.

I would like to ask the Minister what more we can do to maximise Singaporeans' participation, especially at next year's NDP, and whether we could further leverage or harness on the surrounding places around Padang or the Marina Bay, so that more Singaporeans can be part of SG50. And thirdly, the NDP Preview, whether we could consider one more of this preview because the capacity at the Padang is usually much less and perhaps, we can see if we can have one less rehearsal in the earlier stages so that we can have one more Preview for the public to view.

Dr Ng Eng Hen: Mdm Speaker, let me thank the Member for his kind words. Congratulations are due to the participants and the Organising Committee. I will pass on his good remarks.

With regard to maximising capacity and that is indeed what we do around the Marina Bay area. I am glad that the Member has brought it up. It shows that the Organising Committee is on the right track. They have looked around the area. There are possible focal points. I am not giving the distinct details or confirming it, but these are possibilities, because obviously, there are logistical problems. It is right in the middle of town, and if we expand the show, we have to see whether it is feasible.

There are potential sites. Marina Bay, of course, is a potential satellite site. The Marina Promenade is a potential site, but there are other possible sites. The advent of large LED screens with very good resolution makes it possible. I think that is the advance in technology that we have now. We are exploring this seriously to see whether there could be a better option.

To add another NE show is based on the issue of logistics. There can only be so many shows when you are really ready to show to the public, and with the time given and required, we are now putting up all, in all five shows. Three shows are meant for school students, which many of us would agree are useful, and we do not want to rob from them to give it to others. So, we will keep it as three shows.

Adding another show means that we may have to add it on Sunday because we have it on Saturday now, and I think that may be very taxing on the participants.

We will let the Organising Committee evaluate all these options. They will include these inputs as well as, I am sure, inputs from members of the public, but they are quite cognisant that this is NDP 2015, our Golden Jubilee, and they want to put up a good show and include as many Singaporeans as possible either at Padang or the fringe areas.

takesSectionVOList.title: Appeals from Senior Citizens Not Eligible for GST Vouchers Due to Their Residential Address
takesSectionVOList.content:
5 Mr David Ong asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance over the last two years, what is the number of appeals received from senior citizens with qualifying income criteria and no ownership of any residential property but who do not qualify for GST Vouchers because their residential address as an occupier has an annual valuation of above $21,000.

The Senior Minister of State for Finance (Mrs Josephine Teo) (for the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance): Mdm Speaker, the GST Voucher scheme is a broad-based scheme to help lower and middle income households with their expenses, in particular, what they pay in GST. The criteria for the GST Voucher – Cash takes into account an individual's Assessable Income (AI), the Annual Value (AV) of his place of residence and how many properties he owns.

We receive an average of 120 appeals a year from senior citizens – here, I am referring to those who are aged 65 and above – who are below the income threshold and do not own any properties, but are living in properties with Annual Values exceeding $21,000. To put this in context, properties with Annual Values exceeding $21,000 make up the top 15% of owner-occupied homes in Singapore.

There is no perfect way of assessing a person's financial situation. However, a person living in a high-value property with his family is in general more likely to be supported by adequate family resources, even if he or she does not own the property. While there will certainly be exceptions, this approach is broadly equitable and progressive.

The Member can be assured that appeals by those who are unable to qualify for the GST Voucher but are in financial difficulty will be carefully considered. We will continue to review the GST Voucher from time to time, to ensure that it continues to reach those who need it most.

Mr David Ong (Jurong): Thank you, Madam. I thank the Senior Minister of State for the reply. From the many cases I have seen in my Meet-the-People Sessions (MPS) and house visits, many seniors aged 55 and above were pretty upset that the GST Voucher is based on the Annual Valuation of their residence because most of them do not own a property. They are cash-poor, but simply because they live with their children, they are denied the benefits. Since the appeal cases are relatively low for those aged 65 and above, would the Ministry consider extending the benefit to these senior citizens?

Mrs Josephine Teo: Mdm Speaker, the number of properties that falls into this category is actually 15%. If we take 15%, that number in absolute terms will not be very small. What I can suggest that the Member does in such situations where he has encountered seniors in financial difficulty, is to write in to us and I can give him full assurance that we will look into each case carefully; and for deserving cases, certainly, we will do our best to help.

takesSectionVOList.title: Diminished Impact of Pioneer Generation Package on Elderly Pensioners
takesSectionVOList.content:
6 Mr Seah Kian Peng asked the Prime Minister whether a review of the diminished impact of the Pioneer Generation Package for low-income elderly pensioners is being undertaken.

The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Teo Chee Hean) (for the Prime Minister): Mdm Speaker, Government pensioners will continue to receive all their post-retirement medical benefits that they are currently getting.

The Pioneer Generation Package (PGP) honours our Pioneer Generation (PG) by taking care of their healthcare needs. Government pensioners who are Pioneers will also enjoy these Pioneer Generation benefits. All Singaporeans who meet the Pioneers criteria, including Government pensioners, will be eligible for lifelong Medisave top-ups, outpatient care subsidies, and MediShield Life premium subsidies under the Pioneer Generation Package, regardless of their income.

While Government pensioners continue to enjoy their post-retirement medical benefits under their respective medical schemes, they will still benefit from the Pioneer Generation Package. Like other Pioneers, they will receive lifelong annual Medisave top-ups of $200 to $800. In addition, they will also enjoy enhanced Community Health Assist Scheme (CHAS) subsidies at participating General Practitioner and dental clinics. This will reduce their out-of-pocket expenses under their existing medical benefit schemes as pensioners. Pensioners who have moderate to severe functional disabilities will also receive $100 per month under the Pioneer Generation Disability Assistance Scheme.

MediShield Life is a compulsory scheme for all Singaporeans. Hence, Government pensioners will also be enrolled in MediShield Life, and be able to enjoy the benefits of MediShield Life that are beyond the current post-retirement medical benefits that Government pensioners receive in their respective schemes. Our Government pensioners will each receive a letter from the Public Service Division in October with details on how they are being assisted to enrol in MediShield Life.

Overall, the PGP, together with post-retirement medical benefits of Government pensioners, will ensure that Government pensioners who are Pioneers will be better off than before.

takesSectionVOList.title: Graduate Compensation for Non-graduate Preschool Teachers
takesSectionVOList.content:
7 Ms Tin Pei Ling asked the Minister for Social and Family Development whether the move for non-graduate teachers to be considered for graduate compensation based on merits can be applied to the preschool sector, especially for teachers employed by the Anchor Operators.

The Minister for Social and Family Development (Mr Chan Chun Sing): Madam, today, the required qualification for pre-school teaching is a certificate or a diploma in early childhood care and education, which equips preschool teachers with relevant knowledge and competencies to perform their role. The large majority of early childhood educators in the sector, from new teachers to senior teachers and centre leaders, hold a diploma. The Early Childhood Development Agency (ECDA) does not impose a degree as a requirement.

In line with the Applied Study in Polytechnic and ITE Review (ASPIRE) Committee's recommendations, ECDA is working with early childhood operators and practitioners to define the competencies required for different jobs at different levels. With this, we will be able to develop better career progression pathways and continuing professional development programmes for early childhood educators throughout their careers. It will also enable operators to better tie the remuneration of their staff to job size and performance, rather than whether they have a degree or a diploma.

Ms Tin Pei Ling (Marine Parade): I thank the Minister for the clarification. I would like to ask the Minister, based on the conversations that I have with some of the pre-school teachers within my constituency, they shared that there has been a move to encourage them to take on graduate degree kind of programmes and this has asserted quite a bit of pressure on them. I am wondering if the Minister could clarify whether this move is actually signalling that the preschool sector should be moving into a higher skill, higher knowledge kind of basis whereby preschool teachers are expected, moving ahead, to hold a degree before they can dispense proper care for our toddlers or young children. Could the Minister help to address this question?

Mr Chan Chun Sing: Madam, I do not think it is ECDA's policy to encourage people to pursue degrees and I do not think we have ever discussed this in my Ministry. As what we mentioned, what we want is to have people who are appropriately trained, adequate for their jobs and not whether they have a degree or a diploma per se. In fact, today, the vast majority of early childhood educators do not need a degree to be in the sector. And I think we all know that what we are looking for in the early childhood sector are people who can relate to children, people who can care and have the heart for them. A degree may neither be necessary or sufficient in itself. I do not think we will have a policy to say that you must have a degree in order to be an early childhood educator.

But, of course, having said that, for those who would like to upgrade themselves to take on positions with larger job scopes, then if they are found appropriate, we will provide the necessary support for them to upgrade themselves, whether they go for advanced diploma or any other qualifications as necessary.

takesSectionVOList.title: Availability of Qualified Infant Care Personnel
takesSectionVOList.content:
8 Er Dr Lee Bee Wah asked the Minister for Social and Family Development (a) how many new infant care centres were set up in the past 12 months; (b) how do infant care centres cope with the recruitment of qualified carers; (c) what is the range of waiting times for these centres to recruit qualified carers; and (d) whether there is a shortage of qualified carers and, if so, what is being done to address this shortage.

The Minister for Social and Family Development (Mr Chan Chun Sing): Mdm Speaker, the Early Childhood Development Agency (ECDA) monitors infant care demand and works with the preschool Anchor Operators to increase the supply of places in areas of high demand. Between August 2013 and July 2014, ECDA added more than 320 infant care places across 25 childcare centres.

In expanding infant care and child care supply, the availability of manpower is one challenge. ECDA is taking steps to facilitate the recruitment of more infant educarers. For example, the agency organised an Early Childhood Career and Education Fair in May this year. The event attracted more than 1,000 jobseekers, of which 20% were interested in educarer positions.

ECDA has also worked with the Singapore Workforce Development Agency to introduce a traineeship programme for those interested in jobs in the early childhood sector. Trainees will receive a training allowance for the 40 to 80 hours traineeship, and further incentives if they complete the programme and remain in the sector. Twenty preschool operators have come on board the programme since its commencement on 1 July 2014.

In addition, there are Singapore Workforce Skills Qualifications courses for infant educarers that provide mid-career entrants or back-to-work women the flexibility to work in childcare centres while undergoing training. Placement and funding support are available to eligible trainees and centres. There are 160 trainees currently enrolled in these courses.

Er Dr Lee Bee Wah (Nee Soon): Thank you, Mdm Speaker. I have one supplementary question. Every week during my Meet-the-People Sessions (MPS), I have residents who come and ask for help. They have been putting their children on the waiting list of childcare centres. It looks like there is an acute shortage. So, I would like to ask: what is the average waiting time and what more can be done, because every week I have been seeing residents asking for help. I wonder if this problem is unique to Nee Soon South or it is a nation-wide problem.

Mr Chan Chun Sing: Mdm Speaker, let me reply to Er Dr Lee Bee Wah's questions. Indeed, we have a challenge now. And let me explain how ECDA and the Ministry try to work with the various operators to try to meet this challenge of the supply and demand issues in the childcare sector.

On the demand side, we are doing two things to make sure that we have the places at the correct location. The first thing, as Members will know, is that we recently introduced a registration management system. This gives us a better fix of who are the people who are really in the queue or demand. And what we have discovered, very quickly, is that the real or actual demand is a fraction of what the queue may have represented in the past. For those operators who have come on board with us, they are able to deconflict the people who have either got a place somewhere else but never informed them and they should be out of the queue, or there are people who are queuing at multiple centres, sometimes more than 10 centres, and that messes up the projection demand.

So, the first thing we want to do better is for the registration management system to get a better queue system in place, to know the actual demand. That will allow the operators to better site their operations to where it is required. So, that is the first thing – right numbers. The second thing that we want to do better is to make sure that the planning of places in each level is correct. Because while the total number of places is one thing that we are concerned with, we are also concerned with the number of places in each level – whether it is N1, N2, infant care, and so forth, so that there can be better matching. The third thing is a better siting of the location. Some of the high demand areas, like Nee Soon South, Punggol and Woodlands, are where we have allowed the Anchor Operators to quickly expand capacity.

The second set of things that we want to do better on the demand side is to make sure that we get the incentives right, so that we target the subsidies to those people and families who need help the most, so as to avoid a situation where people over-consume the services that they may not necessarily require.

On the supply side, we are also doing four things to make sure that we increase the supply to meet the demand. First, we want to make sure that we strengthen the process of recruitment upstream. We are giving out more scholarships and more training awards, and these will strengthen the pipeline of people coming through to the sector. Second, what we are going to do is to review the career pathways and progression for people to find it attractive and professionally challenging to stay in the sector. Third, we want to make sure that in terms of retention of manpower, we will be able to stretch the career of the early childhood professionals so that we reduce the churn in the sector and also to reduce the training resources we need to pump into this sector. And the last thing is getting the sites right. So, we have placed a lot of emphasis on areas with a larger population of younger families, for example, Woodlands, Punggol, Pasir Ris, Sengkang and some parts of Yishun Town itself. In the eastern part of Yishun Town, we have a lot of new families coming on board.

So, these are various things that we are doing to make sure that we better match the demand and the supply of childcare.

Finally, if I may just share, the structure of the sector is a bit different from some other industries. In this sector, we will have to work very closely with the operators in managing the supply and the demand of child care because this sector is operated by a number of Anchor Operators and many more private operators. So, we have to talk to operators to make sure that they work with us to provide the career opportunities for the teachers to be recruited in the sector and to stay in the sector.

Last but not least, for many of the places like Yishun, what we are seeing is that childcare places are available but the critical shortage is in the recruitment of the teachers. And we have seen some innovative ideas from some other estates whereby they recruit part-timers and women who are hoping to return to work after bringing up their children. And these are auxiliary manpower that we can quickly get in to staff the centres. So, the availability of childcare places is not necessarily the bottleneck for Yishun. It is the recruitment of the educarers that are required and we welcome suggestions on how we can strengthen this pipeline, especially in a very labour-tight market.

Mdm Speaker: Dr Intan.

Dr Intan Azura Mokhtar (Ang Mo Kio): Thank you, Madam. I have a couple of supplementary questions. May I know what is the percentage of those who are undergoing training as preschool teachers who will eventually end up as preschool teachers? Is there a high attrition rate for those who undergo the training programme but did not end up as preschool teachers? My second question is about the traineeship programme for the early childhood sector. I think the Minister probably touched on this a little bit earlier, but I am wondering if a part-time scheme or flexi-adjunct scheme for stay-at-home mothers can be introduced under this traineeship programme, to encourage more stay-at-home mothers to come out and join the preschool sectors as educarers or teachers.

Mr Chan Chun Sing: Mdm Speaker, in response to the first supplementary question from Dr Intan, yes, indeed, the attrition rate is higher than what we would like it to be. We want to bring this down, which is why we are working closely with MOE and the ASPIRE Committee. The first thing we need to do better is to make sure that we counsel the people taking up early childhood care and development courses, that they must have a passion and they must be prepared to undertake the work in the sector. Like many other sectors in the Polytechnics or even in the ITE, there would be people who took up the courses but eventually did not take on the particular job there. I do not have the exact attrition rate but I know that it is much higher than what I would like it to be. I can get the numbers for the Member subsequently. So, this is what we want to do – to reduce the attrition from the pipeline. That is something that we need to work together with the operators and also do counselling.

On her second question on the flexi scheme, as she called it, indeed, that is what we are working closely with the operators to do, not just for the women who are returning to work but also some of the people who have recently retired and are able to play a role in the sector.

In fact, we are prepared to be very flexible to get the manpower into the sector. Recently, we started a scheme, which is to have a registry of all the people who have just left the sector or who have retired from the sector, for them to come back as part-timers to join us as and when they want. They not only provide a ready source of manpower, they also provide supplementary manpower for our own teachers in the sector to go for training. Without them, it will be very difficult for our teachers to upgrade themselves. So, we are doing all this and we will continue to welcome any ideas in order to supplement the manpower in this case.

Mdm Speaker: Er Dr Lee Bee Wah.

Er Dr Lee Bee Wah: Thank you, Mdm Speaker. I had gone round to check all the childcare centres in Nee Soon South. They are all filled up. There is no vacancy. Subsequently, I asked them to expand, and NTUC and PCF expanded but they could not find teachers. So, in fact, the real problem is a shortage of teachers.

I would like to ask the Minister whether the Ministry can take on a more structured way of recruiting on a nation-wide basis – give them more incentives and, perhaps, make the training simpler. I was told that for infant carers, they need to go through a certain duration of training. So, if you were to recruit some of those housewives who are very good in caring and have the experience in caring of babies, if you asked them to go and study, they would say, " Ai tak chek ah?" or "we have to study?", then they would not want to come forward. Perhaps we need to put in more incentives, make the training easier, so that we can have sufficient teachers for our centres.

Mr Chan Chun Sing: Mdm Speaker, indeed, the issue is not the availability of childcare places but the number of people that we can recruit. For example, in Yishun, I think overall and nation-wide, in the last about five years, we have increased the number of places by three times. But the enrolment rate in Yishun is particularly high. Today, you are at about 88% to 89% enrolment, meaning the places are all filled up. The rest have to do with a bit of matching because of the differences in the level.

Indeed, we are trying to expand the number of people that we can recruit. And let me assure the Member and all Members of this House – do not think that it is our intention to make the qualifications very academic; in fact, I do not think many of the qualifications and the courses are that academic. For most trainees, we recruit them on what we call a place-and-train basis, that is, we recruit them, they show the correct aptitude, they show the skill sets and can give assurance to the parents that they are able to take care of the children, then we do the modularised training and upgrade them along the way. That helps us to bring them quickly into the workforce, into the sector, and when we need to, upgrade them on some of the handling skills.

I agree with the Member that many of our parents never went through this kind of courses but they brought us up all right, I hope so. So, what we are looking for are not academic qualifications. What we are looking for are people with the right skill sets that give assurance to the parents who leave their children with us. Some issues in terms of safety, hygiene – these are fundamental aspects of training. And at the same time, educarers must have the heart to want to care for the children. So, they are not going to go for a lot of examinations and tests on the academic side, but more on practical skills that can help them. And we are talking about educarers – we are not talking about the people who are teaching the languages, as those would need certain qualifications – with practical skill sets, and we hope that we can have these people.

takesSectionVOList.title: Effectiveness of Moneylenders Licensing Regime in Reducing Harassment Cases
takesSectionVOList.content:
9 Mr Christopher de Souza asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs whether the current licensing regime for moneylenders has been effective in reducing the rate of unlicensed moneylending-related harassment cases against debtors and innocent neighbours of debtors.

The Senior Minister of State for Home Affairs (Mr Masagos Zulkifli B M M) (for the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs): Mdm Speaker, for the six-month period between January and June 2014, there were 3,235 reported cases of unlicensed moneylending (UML) and UML-related harassment. This is 31.6% lower than the 4,729 cases reported in the same period in 2013. The number of reported cases has been declining steadily since 2010.

The improvement in the UML situation can be attributed to the tough laws enacted, strong enforcement efforts against loanshark syndicates and the high level of community support in the fight against UML activities. Another factor is the presence of licensed moneylenders who provide access to credit for borrowers who are unable to obtain credit from banks or financial institutions and who might otherwise turn to UMLs.

However, there have been cases of loansharks operating under the cover of licensed lenders. Two cases uncovered in recent years have been charged in Court and convicted for UML-related offences. Police will continue to work with the relevant agencies to monitor the activities of licensed moneylenders.

Mr Christopher de Souza (Holland-Bukit Timah): I thank the Senior Minister of State for the encouraging statistics – a reduction of 31.6% over the last six months. I would like to ask a clarification in relation to licensed moneylenders. I have seen quite a number of residents with debts owed to licensed moneylenders, and these moneylenders, as the Senior Minister of State alluded to in his response, sometimes harassed them at the door, at the office, through many phone calls, in order to recover the debts. Can there be more done to eyeball the licensed moneylenders who may be carrying out the tactics of unlicensed moneylenders, in terms of harassment, because I do see my residents having this experience?

Mr Masagos Zulkifli B M M: Licensed moneylenders may take reasonable and legal steps to recover their debts. They must not infringe the laws. This could include contacting the borrowers to ask them to return the loan, or taking legal action to enforce the loan contract. However, as to the concerns raised by the Member, we know some moneylenders do resort to such tactics that the Member has alerted us to. Our point is that moneylenders cannot resort to harassment, vandalism, violence or threatening behaviour when recovering debts – the very things that we try to avoid from unlicensed moneylenders. Borrowers who encounter such behaviour should report the matter to the Police for investigation. Indeed, if we find them committing such offences, they will have their licences suspended, or not renewed or revoked by the Registry of Moneylenders.

The Member might be happy to note that in June this year, MinLaw formed an advisory committee to review the moneylending regulatory regime and will recommend appropriate measures to strengthen it, including the debt collecting practices.

takesSectionVOList.title: Setting Up Community Dispute Resolution Tribunal
takesSectionVOList.content:
10 Mr Liang Eng Hwa asked the Minister for Culture, Community and Youth (a) when will the Community Dispute Resolution Tribunal be set up; (b) what approach will the Tribunal take to resolve disputes between neighbours; and (c) how will the Tribunal be resourced to cope with the increasing numbers of such disputes.

The Minister for Culture, Community and Youth (Mr Lawrence Wong): Madam, the Community Dispute Management Framework (CDMF) is a holistic effort to address community disputes and to promote a more gracious and pleasant living environment for all. Our efforts, in partnership with the community, are focused not just on resolving disputes but also encouraging considerate neighbourly behaviours which are vital to preventing community disputes from arising in the first place. Community-based responses, such as informal mediation by community leaders, and enforcement against anti-social behaviour will be strengthened as part of this framework to resolve community disputes early.

The Community Dispute Resolution Tribunal, which the Member asked about, will be an avenue of last resort to adjudicate long-standing, intractable disputes between neighbours. This is meant as a last recourse after all attempts at resolving what are essentially private matters have been exhausted.

The Tribunal will be established under the auspices of the State Courts, and is slated to be in operation next year. We are working with MinLaw to develop the legislative framework for the Tribunal, and there will be a public consultation on the draft legislation within the next few months.

Essentially, the Court processes and hearings of the Tribunal will be made more streamlined so that long-running disputes can be resolved expeditiously and effectively. Mediation, which is a process that encourages parties to seek a mutually-acceptable solution, will be a key prerequisite for the Tribunal. So, the person who applies to have the dispute heard by the Tribunal must first attempt to mediate with the respondent. If the respondent refuses the applicant's invitations to mediate, the Tribunal can order the parties to attend pre-hearing mediation and record any agreement as a consent order of the Tribunal that can then be enforced accordingly.

We recognise that resources are required to support the effective implementation of the framework and we are working closely with MOF to ensure that the framework, including the Tribunal, will be adequately resourced. 

Mr Liang Eng Hwa (Holland-Bukit Timah): I do agree with the Minister that the Tribunal will be the last resort and we should try to avoid that if possible. But I want to ask the Minister whether this adjudication approach is the only way to compel the resident to behave or act, or are there other ways like the enforcement approach where we can have specific penalty issued by maybe the Police or the HDB officers, or even demerit points systems that some jurisdictions have. In Hong Kong, they have demerit points for households and so on.

So, whether we want to look also at the enforcement approach. Going into adjudication will be really the last resort. The neighbour disputes can be resolved but there will never be neighbourliness between them.

Secondly, it appears that a minority of the residents still are not conscious of what constitutes anti-social behaviour or socially irresponsible behaviour. On that front, whether the MCCY will want to step up on the education and publicity, especially when the new residents move into the flats, and so on, will conduct themselves in a socially responsible way.

Mr Lawrence Wong: Madam, we will certainly step up our public education and public awareness efforts. That is part of the framework which I talked about because we do not want to go to the Tribunal immediately. We want to have residents take ownership of their own community and resolve problems on their own. Certainly, public education is something that we will be doing more of.

We are also going to work through different mechanisms and not just through the Tribunal alone, primarily through informal mediation. We will be providing training for more grassroots leaders, for example, to be able to do such mediation.

The Member talked about enforcement. Enforcement is an approach that works hand-in-hand with the Tribunal. To enforce, you need to have an order; you need to have something to enforce against. The difficulty with enforcement when you are dealing with a private dispute is what do you enforce? Whose side do you decide is saying the right thing? Somebody says "A", the other person says "B". But this is a dispute between two parties, so, what do you enforce, how do you enforce?

That is why you need to go to a Tribunal first. And the Tribunal can then issue a specific performance or injunction, for example, to say that, "This person has been a nuisance, has been behaving in a way that is socially irresponsible, and so, there will be no loud music to be played between these stipulated times." Then that injunction can be enforced. In parallel with the Tribunal, we are also working with MHA to see how we can beef up some of these community enforcement processes.

takesSectionVOList.title: Revisions to ERP Rates
takesSectionVOList.content:
11 Mr Baey Yam Keng asked the Minister for Transport (a) during the quarterly ERP rate reviews in the last three years (excluding school holiday adjustments), how many ERP gantries (and corresponding proportion of the total number of ERP gantries) (i) have not had their rates revised; (ii) have reverted to the previous rates; and (iii) have an upward or downward trend of rate adjustment; (b) how does such data support the position that drivers' behaviour has been influenced positively by ERP; and (c) how will the different method of road pricing through ERP2 influence driving behaviour more effectively.

The Senior Minister of State for Transport (Mrs Josephine Teo) (for the Minister for Transport): Mdm Speaker, in the past three years, 58 of the existing 74 Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) gantries, which is 78%, have not had to have their rates revised. Of the remaining 16 gantries that had rate revisions, eight had an upward trend, while four had a downward trend. The remaining four gantries had no discernible trend. None of the gantries are currently at the rates they started with when they were introduced.

The effectiveness of ERP in influencing drivers' behaviour and keeping our roads congestion-free is not evidenced by the number of gantries that see rate changes, but from the changes in traffic speeds that result from each rate change. Rates are changed when speeds exceed or fall below the range that is optimal for traffic throughput.

For the eight gantries with an upward trend in ERP rates because speeds had fallen below the optimal range, speeds subsequently rose an average of 7% per dollar increase. As for the majority of the gantries which did not need a rate change in the last three years, a balance has been achieved, with the ERP rate sustaining a traffic speed in the optimal range.

With a satellite-based ERP system, we have the flexibility of charging drivers according to the distance they travel on a congested road and not just at specific gantry points. This is an inherently fairer system as those who contribute more to congestion will pay more. The incentive for these drivers to change their time, route or mode of travel would thus be stronger.

Mr Baey Yam Keng (Tampines): Thank you, Mdm Speaker. I do not disagree with the principle of using financial disincentives to control traffic volume and, hence, alleviate traffic congestion. However, I would like to ask the Senior Minister of State, has our consistent tweaking of ERP rates been confusing motorists on keeping track of and remembering the prevailing rate of a specific gantry during different time slots of the day and how effective has this scheme in addressing psychology of motorists and changing their driving behaviour? It is interesting, given that the high percentage of 78% of gantries had not changed their rate in the last three years, would this not indicate that the ERP had not helped to bring down the traffic volume across those gantries?

Mrs Josephine Teo: Mdm Speaker, the ERP rates are changed when the speeds fall outside the optimal range. So, it is not an optimal speed, but it is a range. And the range is 45 km/h to 65 km/h on expressways. The reason why this is a range is so that you do not have to make ERP rate changes so frequently. Speeds have to go below 45 km/h for us to increase the rate. Speeds have to go beyond 65 km/h for us to bring down the rate. And that is precisely to address the Member's concern. We do not want to confuse the motorists too much.

Speaking as a motorist myself, I have to confess that it is probably true of many motorists that even when rate changes are announced in advance through the media, we do not always pay attention. Very often, we only pay attention when our in-vehicle unit goes "beep", we look at the number and realise that it looks different from the last time we were on the road. With that, the motorists take notice and then they have to make a decision on whether they should modify their travelling behaviour.

From that perspective, we try not to adjust the rates too frequently. When it is adjusted, we also make sure that the amount is significant enough for people to take notice in the hope that this will cause them to rethink their driving behaviour. Not all will respond because even with the rate changes, they may consider that it is still well worth the time savings for them. Alternatively, they may assess that they have no better alternative but to travel in that particular time slot. But each time there is a rate change, we do notice that there are certain drivers who have changed their travelling pattern, and that is why there has been an impact on the speeds of travel on the particular stretches of road where ERP rate changes have occurred.

Er Dr Lee Bee Wah (Nee Soon): Thank you, Mdm Speaker. I would like to ask the Senior Minister of State, will the Ministry look into reviewing the evening ERP along CTE to zero?

Mrs Josephine Teo: May I make sure I understand the Member's question clearly – you are proposing to reduce the ERP rate, that is, to abolish it completely? The current traffic speeds along that stretch do not justify such a consideration.

takesSectionVOList.title: Preventing Major Underground Gas Leaks
takesSectionVOList.content:
12 Dr Lim Wee Kiak asked the Minister for Trade and Industry in the light of the recent gas pipe explosion in Taiwan (a) what are the safety features or processes in place here to prevent a catastrophic gas pipe leak, especially in crowded areas; (b) how frequently are checks carried out to detect if there are any leaks in all the gas pipes and how are these maintenance checks carried out; (c) during the past five years, how many cases of gas leaks were detected; and (d) is there a replacement programme for old pipes and what is the age of the oldest underground gas pipe.

13 Er Dr Lee Bee Wah asked the Minister for Trade and Industry (a) what measures are in place to maintain all underground gas and water pipes in good working order; (b) what is the lifespan of these pipes before they are replaced; (c) how are underground pipes inspected; and (d) what are the safeguards to prevent leaks that can cause a serious explosion. 

The Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry (Mr Lee Yi Shyan) (for the Minister for Trade and Industry): Mdm Speaker, may I take Question Nos 12 and 13 together?

Mdm Speaker: Yes, please.

Mr Lee Yi Shyan: Ensuring the safety of our utilities infrastructure is a key priority. EMA has put in place robust regulatory requirements and conducts regular inspections to ensure the reliability and safety of Singapore's gas pipelines.

Careful attention is paid to the planning and design of our gas network. SP Power Grid (SPPG), which manages Singapore's gas network, must conduct a risk assessment exercise and meet the requirements set by SCDF and other authorities, before constructing a pipeline.

All high-pressure gas pipelines are constructed using high-strength steel with anti-corrosion coating. Pipelines on the mainland are buried at a depth of 1.5 metres on average and further protected by concrete slabs to ensure pipeline integrity. Gas that is distributed to consumers is also odorised to facilitate detection in the event of any leak.

To ensure that the pipeline network remains in good working condition, SPPG carries out various surveillance and maintenance measures, as required by the Gas Transporter Licence and relevant codes of practice such as the Gas Safety Code and Gas Supply Code. SPPG continuously monitors pipeline pressure and flow for any anomalies. It also surveys the pipeline network regularly for leaks using gas detectors. Such surveys are conducted more frequently in crowded and residential areas. For example, SPPG inspects the pipelines in the vicinity of MRT stations on a monthly basis, while non-residential areas are surveyed on an annual basis.

In addition, SPPG conducts annual mechanical inspections of critical pipeline components and inspects high-pressure pipelines using pipeline inspection gauges every five years to ensure that the pipelines remain in good working conditions. EMA conducts annual audits and enforcement checks to ensure that SPPG carries out the pipeline surveillance and maintenance processes as scheduled.

The service life of gas pipelines is about 50 years. SPPG systematically replaces pipelines before the end of their service lives, or earlier if the condition of these pipelines is found to have deteriorated. Our high-pressure pipelines are less than 20 years old, so they are well within the estimated service lifespan.

As for water pipes, PUB's water mains are relatively new, with an average age of 24 years. Since the 1980s, older pipes have been systematically replaced with cement-lined ductile iron and steel mains, which are more durable and have an expected lifespan of 70 years. A strict maintenance regime is in place to ensure that our water pipes remain in good working condition. There is a dynamic leak detection programme in which all water pipes are checked for leaks at least once a year. Our leak rate is six leaks per 100 km of pipes each year, which is among the lowest in the world.

Dr Lim Wee Kiak (Nee Soon): Mdm Speaker, I would like to thank the Senior Minister of State for the reply. I would like to ask the Senior Minister of State what lessons can be learnt from the Taiwanese experience, as well as what is the possibility of such an incident happening in Singapore. I would also like to ask, for example, about water pipes. There are ground movements and as Members of Parliament, we do receive complaints from residents about water pipe leakages as well as bursting of pipes. Water pipes may not be as dangerous as gas pipes. So, I am just wondering what other measures are taken to make sure that such instances do not happen, and in the past, how many of such cases have happened in Singapore.

Mr Lee Yi Shyan: Madam, in the Taiwanese case, the recent explosion is due to a pipeline supplying petrochemicals to a chemical plant. The gas carried there is propene (C3H6), which is different from the natural gas that our SPPG is distributing. Propene is a heavier gas than air. So, when it leaks, it tends to stay underground until it gathers a bigger mass, which makes it more dangerous. Whereas natural gas, in our case, is lighter. So, if it leaks, it tends to dissipate into the air quickly, therefore, reducing a volume build-up and explosion.

Having said that, they are all inflammable. The results of the investigation in Taiwan have not been released, so, we probably can take some lessons from that incident at a later stage. In the case of Singapore, I mentioned SPPG being the one that manages our natural gas distribution pipelines on the mainland mostly, whereas our petrochemical pipelines are mostly concentrated on Jurong Island. And therefore, they are supervised by SCDF which imposes in them another and more stringent set of construction, operation and maintenance regime. We have confidence that the two sets of pipelines are separately managed, and there is sufficient rigour and robustness in the way that they are maintained and operated.

The Member also asked about the frequency of leaks. For high-pressure gas pipelines, there was one case that took place in 2012 on Jurong Island. The leak was detected early, so there was no casualty or fatality. It was rectified in a relatively short time, as the gas supply was resumed after a short while.

Over the last five years, there were 500 minor gas leaks – 300 were detected by SPPG and 200 were reported. These represent a frequency of 0.1 incident per 1 km of pipeline. This makes us very comparable to Hong Kong, and well ahead of other cities like New York, Melbourne and London.

takesSectionVOList.title: Singapore's Position on Kidnapping of 200 Girls by Rebels in Nigeria
takesSectionVOList.content:
14 Mrs Lina Chiam asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs whether Singapore has any bilateral ties with Nigeria and, if not, whether Singapore has taken any steps at the international level to support and assist the Nigerian Government for the release of the 200 Nigerian girls kidnapped by rebels more than three months ago.

The Senior Minister of State for Foreign Affairs (Mr Masagos Zulkifli B M M) (for the Minister for Foreign Affairs): Mdm Speaker, Singapore and Nigeria established diplomatic relations on April 1970. Our ties with Nigeria are very good. I recently met the Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, Prof Viola Onwuliri, when we hosted several African Foreign Ministers whom we invited to Singapore.

Mdm Speaker, the hon Member, I believe, is referring to the incident on 14 April 2014 when Boko Haram, a Nigerian militant Islamist Group, abducted more than 200 girls from a school. The incident captured worldwide attention. More than 50 of the abductees managed to escape but the rest are believed to be still in captivity.

We sympathise with the plight of the abductees and their families. We strongly condemn the abduction of innocent girls. Singapore has not been approached by the Nigerian Government to render assistance. We also do not have the same capabilities as the US, UK or France, which had earlier provided intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance support to the Nigerian government. 

Mrs Lina Chiam (Non-Constituency Member): I would like to ask the Senior Minister of State a supplementary question. Will the Singapore Government do anything to help the Nigerian girls? This is a global moral obligation. Could we do something to help them, or what can the Government do in this case? Any suggestion?

Mr Masagos Zulkifli B M M: We should be mindful about being proactive in offering assistance. This is also to respect our bilateral partners. When I met the Nigerian Minister of State, she did not broach the matter. I think we should respect that.

takesSectionVOList.title: Housing Grants for Married Children to Buy HDB Flats Near Parents
takesSectionVOList.content:
15 Mr Christopher de Souza asked the Minister for National Development (a) what are the current policies on providing housing grants or incentives for married children to purchase flats in close proximity with their parents, and vice versa; and (b) whether the Ministry is considering any enhancements to its current policies, in order to strengthen the state of family bonding and inter-generational care in Singapore.

The Minister for National Development (Mr Khaw Boon Wan): Madam, helping extended families live together or close by for mutual care and support has been a long-standing priority for this Government. Currently, we help support this in six ways.

First, under the Married Child Priority Scheme, those who apply for a new HDB flat near their parents or married children get double the ballot chances. Those who apply for a new flat to live together get triple the ballot chances.

Second, under the Multi-Generation Priority Scheme, we allow married children and their parents to jointly apply for a pair of flats in the same Build-To-Order (BTO) project and we set aside flats for this purpose. We set aside up to 15% of the Studio Apartment, 2-room and 3-room flat supply for parents and the corresponding number of 2-room and larger flats for their married children.

Third, under the Studio Apartment Priority Scheme, we reserve half of the new Studio Apartment supply for eligible seniors who apply for Studio Apartments near their married children or their existing home.

Fourth, in September 2013, we introduced 3Gen flats, at the suggestion of Er Dr Lee Bee Wah, which feature four bedrooms and three bathrooms, to facilitate multi-generation families who wish to live in the same flat. I always credit Er Dr Lee Bee Wah as the mother of 3Gen flats. Our first 3Gen BTO was, correctly, launched in Nee Soon.

Fifth, first-timers buying a resale flat to stay near or with their parents or married children are eligible for the Higher-Tier CPF Housing Grant for Family of $40,000, which is $10,000 more than the standard CPF Housing Grant.

Sixth, we ensure that the income ceiling for the purchase of a HDB flat is set at a higher level for extended families who buy a flat to live together.

In the recent series of Housing Conversations on "Closer Families, Stronger Ties", we received many valuable suggestions and feedback from Singaporeans on how we could further help extended families live together or nearby. We will take these into consideration in our on-going policy reviews. 

Mr Christopher de Souza (Holland-Bukit Timah): I thank the Minister for the response. Perhaps, living in mature estates presents more difficulty for children to want to move in close to their parents. May I ask the Minister's clarification on this particular issue, where in a mature estate, for example, the constituency I serve, Ulu Pandan, there is limited space to build more flats. HDB is good at finding pockets of space and building flats, and children would move into those flats to be close to their parents. But the parents usually live in older flats which are possibly coming up for en bloc development. My question is: would HDB look at it in a considered fashion to try to find space even for the older flats to undergo en bloc within that mature estate setting? I know it may be a tall order, but I would be grateful if consideration could be given for that.

Mr Khaw Boon Wan: Madam, indeed, it is a tall order. And for mature estates, there are particular challenges for the simple reason that land for a big number of BTO construction is less available than in non-mature estates. But because this is such an important social objective, we try very hard and we continue to strive to the best of our abilities to fulfil those needs. There are various ways we go about it. If the Member checked back on the last three years of BTO launches, he will note that I have launched quite a number in several mature estates. Within the next 12 months, there will be several BTO launches in several mature estates. Whether these would be in the Member's ward, I do not know, but wherever possible, we try to do so.

Then, there is always the possibility of en bloc or SERS development. There is yet another avenue which is resale flat. There are a large number of resale flats, more so than the number of new flats that I can build. In fact, until this current property cycle, most people buy their flats through resale transactions – the ratio was about 60-40; 60% from resale and 40% from BTO flats.

But the last three years have been unusual. As I step up the number of BTO launches and kept the prices very competitive, now, almost 95% of young couples buy directly from HDB. This cannot be the steady state. But now that Cash-over-Valuation (COV) has turned negative, with many transactions settled below market valuation, it opens up huge opportunities for buyers. I see that possibility growing within the next many months.

The short answer is yes. In MND, we try very hard to meet the aspirations of both parents – especially parents – and their children wanting to be able to live close by and we will do our very best. Of course, there is, yet, another option which is the parents may decide to sell off their flats and move with their children to the new towns. Theoretically, it is logical and possible, but I know many parents are very reluctant. As we have heard yesterday, they are used to the hawkers, to a particular wet market stallholder and they find it very difficult to move to a new place. But we will try to change such mindset.

Mr Baey Yam Keng (Tampines): Madam, a follow-up on the Minister's last point about parents living in mature estates finding it difficult to relocate into a new estate, would the Ministry consider giving financial incentives for these parents to move? The CPF Grant that the Minister had mentioned earlier, I think, typically does not apply to these parents because they would have enjoyed previous subsidies. And, therefore, I hope that the Ministry would consider giving, perhaps, cash grants to incentivise parents to move into the new location and settle down there.

Mr Khaw Boon Wan: This particular idea, Madam, was, in fact, raised a couple of times during our recent Housing Conversations. To probe further, we asked the participants, "How much do you think will move you?" And the figure is something I cannot afford. It is six digits! As I said, we will try within our capabilities and financial limits to meet such aspiration. But if some parents can change their attitudes and be prepared to try out a new town, you may discover better new environment – maybe in Yishun.

Mr Christopher de Souza: I was also hoping the Minister would also share his thoughts on en blocs within a mature estate. My follow-up question really was also in relation to the elderly in mature estates worrying that due to a lack of space, if they were to undergo en bloc, they will be moved outside the precinct. Would one of the considerations, or major considerations, for MND be to have the en bloc flats within the same area as far as possible, because location is actually the top priority for these elderly people?

Mr Khaw Boon Wan: I heard that to mean SERS, right?

Mr Christopher de Souza: Yes.

Mr Khaw Boon Wan: En bloc is a private condominium term but, in HDB, we call it SERS. And, yes, we will do SERS wherever it is "SERS-able".  [Laughter]

takesSectionVOList.title: Window Grilles for HDB Rental Flats
takesSectionVOList.content:
16 Mr Baey Yam Keng asked the Minister for National Development (a) what is the reason why HDB rental flats do not come with window grilles; (b) whether tenants who install their own window grilles need not remove them upon their vacation of the flat when the grilles are still in good working condition; and (c) whether HDB can review this policy to reduce the cost for rental tenants.

17 Mr Png Eng Huat asked the Minister for National Development whether HDB will consider making window grilles a standard safety feature for rental flats. 

The Minister of State for National Development (Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman) (for the Minister for National Development): Madam, may I have your permission to take Question Nos 16 and 17 together? 

Mdm Speaker: Yes, please.

Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman: Madam, HDB does not provide window grilles as a standard feature in its flats, whether sold or rental, as they are not considered essential by all households. However, rental tenants may install their own window grilles. If they are unable to afford to do so and have safety concerns, HDB will help to install the grilles on a case-by-case basis.

Rental tenants who have installed their own grilles do not need to remove them when they move out of the rental flat if the grilles are still in good condition. 

Mdm Speaker: Mr Baey.

Mr Baey Yam Keng (Tampines): Thank you, Madam. I can understand that HDB flats are designed with the basic necessities or essential necessities to keep costs down. But I would like the Ministry to see window grilles in high-rise living as a safety requirement rather than non-essential item, especially for low-income families who need help with our rental housing scheme. For these families earning less than $1,500, and especially with young children, even a few hundred dollars can be a lot of money.

I would like to ask the Minister of State what is the proportion of rental tenants with young children and what is the proportion who have sought approval to either install window grilles on their own or that HDB has helped to install window grilles for them at HDB's cost. What is the application procedure and what is the success rate?

Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman: Madam, let me contextualise the availability of grilles in rental flats. Although I have mentioned that we do not put it as a standard feature today, historically, rental flats which were mainly built in the 1960s and 1970s were originally designed without window grilles. Tenants who wished to install it at that time can do so at their own cost. But over the years, as part of the Government's efforts to improve the living conditions of our rental flat tenants, window grilles were included as one of the improvement items and installed during the various upgrading programmes. For example – rental flats – the Main Upgrading Programme, the Project LIFE rental flats upgrading project.

Households with young children generally welcome the provision of these window grilles for safety reasons. However, some tenants also provide feedback that the window grilles caused a "caged in" kind of feeling in the smaller flats and hindered or obstructed some of their activities, for example, especially for the elderly ones, who have difficulties when they want to hang out their clothes. Therefore, HDB, after having upgraded some of these rental flats with window grilles, in 2007, we had a review and we decided to exclude window grilles as essential items for fitting in rental flats for the following reasons: one, is as mentioned, not all rental tenants need window grilles and it is consistent with the non-provision of grilles in purchase and rental flats and, at the same time, based on the feedback that we have received.

The new rental flats which were built after 2007, when we resumed our rental building programme, were not installed with grilles. With all the upgraded rental flats today, with an existing stock of 109 blocks, we do have about 74% of them that are already provided with window grilles, meaning that three-quarters of our rental flat tenants are already living in rental flats with window grilles.

Mr Baey asked about the proportion of our tenants who are living with children below the age of 12. Today, about 15% of our rental flat tenants are made up of families or households with children below the age of 12. So, the number is quite small.

We had another review recently, in April 2014. HDB decided to install window grilles for deserving households on a case-by-case basis if the tenant meets one of the two following guidelines: one, is that the family with young children aged below 12. For those who meet this criterion, HDB will assist them in installing the window grilles. At the same time, households where family members with medical conditions, for example, hyper activity, those with intellectual disability, or hallucinations, and there are safety concerns for these families.

To date, we have received about 60 requests for such cases. In the last two years, HDB has assisted about 27 cases and installed the grilles for them. The others who do not meet the criteria, we asked them to seek help from FSOs, VWOs, because they are not seen as families with young children at risk or maybe having safety concerns.

Henceforth, from April this year, families with children below the age of 12 will be assisted. But as I have mentioned earlier, we do have a stock of rental flats that are already installed with grilles, and if those flats are available for tenancy, we will actually offer those to meet the needs and match the profile of families or households with children below the age of 12.

takesSectionVOList.title: Take-up Rates for Childcare and Paternity Leave Schemes in Civil Service
takesSectionVOList.content:
18 Mr Seah Kian Peng asked the Prime Minister given that amongst all eligible public officers, only 72% used the 6-day childcare leave, 48% used the two-day extended childcare leave and 78% used their paternity leave, what are the underlying causes for these relatively low take-up rates.

The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Teo Chee Hean) (for the Prime Minister): Mdm Speaker, the public service supports the well-being and work-life needs of our officers. On top of vacation leave, officers are provided with a range of pro-family leave benefits to help them balance their family and work commitments. And these include childcare, paternity, maternity and parent-care leave. Officers utilise their leave benefits on a needs basis. Rather than focusing on the utilisation rate for specific leave types, we will continue to ensure that pro-family leave benefits are made known and available to officers so that they can utilise them when they need to do so. 

Mr Seah Kian Peng (Marine Parade): I thank Deputy Prime Minister for the answer. A few supplementary questions. As Members know, I have been pushing a lot on paternity leave, and I am glad this was legislated.

I appreciate the efforts by the Government in giving our civil servants all these pro-family measures. The Deputy Prime Minister mentioned about needs basis, I recognise that. I do think that all those, whether it is childcare leave and, in particular, paternity leave, I think we would want every father to take the paternity leave that is available to them to spend some time with their children.

Which is why my question is: what are the underlying causes that fathers are not taking up their paternity leave? This is something which we would want to encourage our civil servants to do, to proactively tell them, "Please go and take leave and spend time with your children and family".

I am asking what are the underlying causes and to, perhaps, from the top-down signalling approach, encourage our public officers to celebrate the joy of having children to, please, take their paternity leave amongst other things.

Mr Teo Chee Hean: Mdm Speaker, I did not see a question there. I do not think I need to respond to it. I do not disagree with Mr Seah.

Mdm Speaker: Order. End of Question Time. Dr Amy Khor has asked for the floor.
