takesSectionVOList.title: Applied Study in Polytechnics and Institute of Technical Education Review (ASPIRE)
takesSectionVOList.content:
[(proc text) Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [8 September 2014], (proc text)]

[(proc text) "That this House (1) endorses the Applied Study in Polytechnics and ITE Review Report (Paper Misc 3 of 2014), which sets out this Government's policy to ensure that all Singaporeans, whatever their qualifications, enjoy full opportunities to upgrade and progress during their working lives; and (2) supports a tripartite approach to instil a culture of lifelong learning, and to recognise and reward individuals based on their skills and performance." – [Senior Minister of State (Ministry of Education)]. (proc text)]

[(proc text) Question again proposed. (proc text)]

3.00 pm

Mr Lim Biow Chuan (Mountbatten): Mdm Speaker, the ASPIRE report has four basic recommendations.

First, better choices: helping Polytechnic and ITE students make better choices for their education and careers, both in school and after graduation;

Second, equipping students: this is to equip young Singaporeans with good skills foundation to face challenges and to seize opportunities;

Third, deeper skills: creating more opportunities for Polytechnic and ITE graduates to deepen their skills and excel in their chosen field.

Finally, multiple paths: building more paths for Polytechnic and ITE graduates to advance in their careers.

The report has been well received. One key focus of this Motion is how can we ensure that all Singaporeans, regardless of their qualifications, enjoy full opportunities to upgrade and progress during their working lives.

Madam, education has always been seen as the universal leveller. It allows someone from a poorer socio-economic background to secure a better job because he or she has better training and better educational qualifications and, hence, has a higher probability of success in life. In Singapore, many parents encourage their children to secure a degree in the belief that they can get a better job and secure better pay.

You can see this each time any one of us visits a house. You will see, occupying the place of honour in the living room is probably a framed photo of the family with all the children dressed up in their convocation gowns, demonstrating that the children have graduated.

However, I recognise that not everyone is academically inclined to go down the path of University education. Some students may be more suited for technical studies; some may not be interested in academic pursuits and prefer to do "hands-on" kind of work; some may be very good in their work but somehow do not have the right techniques to score well in exams.

For some of these young people, they may be better off developing their personal interest and pursuing their dreams. I know of many people who do not have University degrees but who have done exceedingly well in their careers because they have other lifeskills which are equally important in life.

Yesterday, the hon Member Ms Denise Phua had named some prominent people who did not go to college but had done well in life. The Straits Times had recently highlighted several individuals who had done well in life, even though they do not have a degree.

However, regardless of the number of success stories which we may share, many young people, whether from the ITEs or the Polytechnics still aspire for a University degree because they believe that it is the only path to success in Singapore. Very frankly, I think many parents share the same view. I am sure every parent in this House would also hope that their child can get to University. In fact, many of them would also have a bank account to provide for overseas university studies, in case their child cannot make it to the local Autonomous Universities.

Thus, it is very important for the Government to assure our young people that, regardless of their educational qualifications, everyone will have opportunities to realise their potential and to progress in life.

A degree, whilst important for the training of the mind, should not be the only way in which a person can attain success in life. Our ITE and Polytechnic graduates must know that as long as they have the right attitude, the right competence, are willing to work hard and contribute to the organisation, with sufficient experience, they will be able to achieve the success which they have worked hard for.

The recommendations by the ASPIRE Committee go a long way to assure our young people that the Government is committed to helping them achieve their fullest potential.

For the ASPIRE report to have meaningful impact, we need to do more. First, we need to have a better explanation of ASPIRE and for greater buy-in from the young people and their parents.

At a recent dialogue with residents and grassroots leaders, some of them had asked me: what is the message from the Government? Are they saying that it is not necessary to get a degree anymore? They pointed to newspaper articles which highlighted non-graduates who had performed well in their careers.

Some residents had queried whether the Government intends to cut down more University places and, hence, are promoting ITE and Polytechnic education. Other residents had highlighted that, as a nation, we cannot have too many graduates; otherwise, there will be a glut of graduates who cannot find suitable jobs and this will eventually lead to greater resentment. Others had declared that they will definitely want their children to get a University degree because society see those without a degree as failures.

Thus, there is some misunderstanding about the recommendations of the ASPIRE committee. I would like to ask the Senior Minister of State what are the plans of the Government to explain more about the ASPIRE recommendations. How can we better explain to parents and students that a degree is still useful as a training of the mind? However, not having a degree does not mean that there will be no progress. Would our young and their parents be persuaded that there are, indeed, multiple pathways to advance in their careers? How useful would postgraduate training be in helping them deepen their skills? What kind of certifications would be issued and would these certifications be recognised? More information and clarifications will help Singaporeans understand the ASPIRE recommendations better and buy into these recommendations.

Next, the Government should take the lead to provide multiple pathways. Within the Civil Service, there is a clear difference between staff who are graduates and those who are non-graduates. I recall years ago when I graduated from University and I was considering a job with the Legal Service. The advertisement said, "Only those with First Class Honours or a good Second Upper will be considered." So, the type of Honours degree makes a difference.

There is also a difference between graduates who are scholars and those who are non-scholars, commonly known as "farmers". The distinction is even more stark if one compares graduate scholars in the Civil Service and graduate scholars who are from the elite Administrative Service. Their progress or promotion depends on whether they are graduates or non-graduates, whether they are scholars from the Administrative Service. But this distinction is not real because, in the private sector, the employer looks at your skills, your experience and whether you can deliver results.

Yesterday, Deputy Prime Minister Teo had stated in a reply to my Parliamentary Question that the Civil Service will provide more opportunities to support the aspirations of all our officers, graduates as well as non-graduates, and will continue to reward all officers who show good performance and readiness to take on larger roles. I am, indeed, glad to hear that position.

As long as the Government continues to maintain a distinction between graduates and non-graduates, we will struggle to persuade Singaporeans that they can progress in society based on their skills, contributions and experience. I call on the Government to take the lead in changing the mindset of Singaporeans. This will be a long journey as we need students and parents to be convinced that a person can have multiple pathways to success regardless of their educational qualifications. The Government can take the lead by showing them that skills and experience are just as important as qualifications.

Our civil servants should be given every opportunity to progress in their careers not based on whether they have a degree; but due consideration should also be given to how they perform in the delivery of their task. One good example is the appointment of Mrs Elaine Quek – this was reported in The Straits Times. She is a non-graduate and she was appointed as principal of Maha Bodhi School. I truly hope that we can have many more similar cases in the Civil Service, where employees are promoted based on their skills and experience.

Finally, mindset change. The ASPIRE report talks about the need for a mindset change. One important change which is critical is the need for all of us to respect every job and value every individual for what they do. Currently, there seems to be a bias in favour of white collar kind of work. Parents generally want their children to work in offices and to shun work that would require them to wear a uniform or to work in non air-conditioned places.

I would like to ask the Minister what else can the Government do to persuade our citizens to respect every job and to value every worker. Can we do more to acknowledge the contributions of the blue collar workers like our cleaners, our school attendants, our service staff at supermarkets or restaurants?

They all play an important role in making Singapore a better place to live in. There is no reason why we should treat such people with less respect. Perhaps, the Government can explore ways in which skilled technicians or people with strong vocational skills or strong service skills can be better remunerated for their expertise. We can also consider redesigning some of these jobs so that they carry more responsibilities. For example, bus drivers are now called "bus captains" with more responsibilities for the passengers in their buses. Our cooks are now called chefs. Our bank tellers used to be called clerks, but they are all now capable of providing financial advice.

The ASPIRE recommendations will have a long-term impact on Singaporeans. I support the recommendations. I look forward to the Government working with Members of Parliament and the people of Singapore to enable Singaporeans to realise their fullest potential, regardless of their starting point in life.

3.09 pm

Mr Thomas Chua Kee Seng (Nominated Member) (In Mandarin): [Please refer to Vernacular Speech.] Mdm Speaker, fellow Members of Parliament, good afternoon! Firstly, I would like to declare that I am the President of the Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry and the Chairman and Managing Director of Teckwah Industrial Corporation. Today, I would like to speak about improving the technical education from the business viewpoint.

Last month, the Applied Study in Polytechnics and ITE Review (ASPIRE) Committee made 10 recommendations to transform our vocational education. I have discussed this with the business community and we are all very pleased to learn about this. The shortage of local skilled workers has been in existence for much too long and this improvement can be said to be a welcome rain after a protracted drought.

Many SMEs, especially those in traditional industries, rely on a pool of skilled, experienced and loyal older workers to be responsible for their operations. Although they have tried all means, it is extremely difficult to attract the young generation into their industries. They have no choice but to impart the skills to foreign workers. Once the foreign workers leave, there is a vacuum in the pool of skilled workers. Currently, this is a serious human resource problem confronting our local SMEs. We are thus very supportive that the Government is embarking on improving our vocational education, to help enterprises groom a pool of skilled workers.

However, in the composition of the ASPIRE Committee, business representatives practically all come from large corporations and MNCs, and there are no SMEs or traditional industries among them. When we look at the name list of the Committee members, SMEs begin to worry that in revising the course curriculum, planning for internship and so on, SMEs' needs may not be considered. Young people would only see large corporations in the newspapers' limelight; they will thus be inclined to join these large companies and not be willing to join SMEs.

Singapore faces a manpower shortage. The pool of young people is like a cake, which every industry is eyeing. Large corporations and MNCs have big appetite and very strong appeal. Very quickly, this cake would be entirely eaten up by them. In view of this, I urge industry and trade associations to collaborate closely with ASPIRE, and actively inform the Committee of the needs of your industries and manpower requirements, and participate in the process of enhancing vocational education. Only by engaging actively in the process can SMEs receive the attention you need.

Looking through the report, with regard to Recommendation 7 on launching the Place-and-Train programme, and under point 4.6 on page 29, it clearly states that Polytechnic and ITE graduates would be matched to progressive employers committed to support the internship programme. Therefore, SMEs and industry associations need to act fast.

At the same time, I also urge the Government that when reviewing the vocational education system, it could devote special attention to the SMEs. Implementing the Place-and-Train programme requires companies to make certain adjustments in their human resource management policies. Compared to large corporations, SMEs are considerably weaker in this regard. However, they could integrate resources through their industry and trade associations. I hope the Government could consider rolling out related assistance schemes to ensure that local SMEs do not miss out on the chance to participate.

Transforming vocational education is an arduous journey that would benefit both the nation and the people. I believe that under the Government's able leadership and with the hard work of the tripartite partners, we would be assured of creating a career pathway for our young people which will allow them to fulfil their potentials!

On this note, I support the Applied Study in Polytechnics and ITE Review report.

3.16 pm

Ms Lee Li Lian (Punggol East): Mdm Speaker, the recommendations made by the ASPIRE Committee represent a welcome shift in how we approach education and how we enable Singaporean students to succeed as they choose different educational paths. This shift is important as we recognise the growing diversity of Singaporeans and their interests, as well as the changing needs of the markets.

Today, I will focus on recommendations on how students in ITEs and Polytechnics can get meaningful work experience through internships and Place-and-Train or apprenticeship programmes. Work experience is an excellent opportunity for students to learn practical aspects of industry-specific jobs, not just the theoretical mechanics in the classroom. This helps them achieve a high level of competence and understanding of their own interests and abilities.

While I agree with the ASPIRE recommendations that we need to enhance internships in collaboration with industry partners and expand options for students through apprenticeship programmes, what is critical is how we go about implementing these recommendations to bring real benefit to our ITE and Polytechnic students.

The value of work experience. Madam, during my time at Ngee Ann Polytechnic, I did an internship for four months at the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) as part of my Business Studies course. Although it was for a short period, it was a very fulfilling and pivotal experience for me. I was fortunate enough to be assigned to an encouraging mentor who dedicated time to setting goals for me and evaluating my progress. My internship gave me greater insights into that particular industry and what I realised was that tax and accounting were not quite the right path for me, something I may not have realised till much later, if not for this internship.

Every student, regardless of whether they are in University, Polytechnic or ITE should have the opportunity to explore and demonstrate their skills through quality work trainings.

Companies will also have greater exposure to students from Polytechnics and ITEs. They can evaluate them first-hand, based on skills and capabilities, and not just on paper qualifications. This would help reduce any perception that employers may have towards students from particular institutions.

Challenges. While work experience programmes are becoming increasingly popular today, one challenge is ensuring some level of consistency in terms of what students can expect to gain during their internships. Internship and apprenticeship programmes are often voluntary and informal, so students can get vastly different experiences. While I benefited from my internship, many of my peers who had done internships elsewhere felt that they did not have much guidance, and others felt that they were given pointless tasks where they did not learn. I have learnt of similar experiences today when speaking with students in my ward.

Without a formal programme structure, there is plenty of opportunity for abuse. There are situations where employers see interns as cheap labour and are herded from one department to another to fill gaps in any manpower crunches without any focus on their development.

As internship programmes are not extensive across courses and not all students have the opportunity to participate, students who are looking for work experience may source for internships on their own with individual companies. I have come across situations where outside a formal internship programme, interns may not even get an allowance and end up doing tasks that the company needs them to fill in for, without much supervision.

Therefore, it is critical to enhance and expand official internship programmes led by the educational institutions, with companies agreeing to participate and implement more formal programme structures.

While we do not want to over-formalise practical training either, there must be some guidelines to ensure that students do gain from their experiences, are monitored and get significant work-ready skills. This should include having company orientations, regular mentorship and evaluation sessions and, of course, clearer goals, timelines and outcomes, including relevant certification, for both students and the company.

Making firm and clear commitments. I think we can agree that internship and apprenticeship programmes are critical for students to make well-informed choices and acquire the right skills for successful future careers. We should aspire for each student to have exposure to at least one internship or apprenticeship programme during his or her time in ITE or Polytechnic, even going so far as ensuring that formal work experience becomes part of their course requirement. Mdm Speaker, we must commit to setting clear goals going forward so that the desired outcomes of the ASPIRE report can be made a reality.

Active consultation with industry. In order to ensure a successful internship or apprenticeship programme that is available to more ITE and Polytechnic students, there must be an active drive to attract a network of committed companies across industries to support, share and mentor students through internship and apprenticeship programmes.

There must be adequate consultation between education institutions and companies from identified industries to ensure that programmes help students further develop their skills and learning, in line with the needs and expectations of industries today.

We need to also help companies see the value of being part of internship or apprentice programmes. The benefits include having access to a steady source of skilled pre-professionals which can address manpower needs, as well as the opportunity to source for talent for future recruitment, and get fresh ideas and perspectives from students to solve company challenges. For SMEs especially, who often struggle with manpower shortages, it allows them to tap into a flexible, short-term and cost-effective workforce.

We must also recognise companies who are seen as actively investing in the student community and creating opportunities for them, aligned with national initiatives.

While looking at shifting mindsets, there may also be a need to incentivise companies to commit to official work experience programmes, by reducing some of the short-term challenges they might face so that they can see the long-term benefits.

Many companies, especially SMEs, lack the manpower to supervise and mentor interns and to provide them with adequate training while on the job. They may also lack the budget to compensate interns and apprentices.

In addition, while it is true that interns can help address a company's manpower needs, there will be students who lack initiative and treat internships as simply a course requirement or something to put on their CVs without putting in much effort. Some may only expect to do more "interesting tasks", and such interns always require more supervision and can add to the workload for the company. Such factors are disincentives for companies with limited resources.

While lead institutions must encourage a culture of responsibility amongst their students and employers, there are real constraints that may need to be dealt with more specifically to incentivise companies to support such programmes.

Some examples of how incentivisation can take place would be to offer grants or funding to cover the costs of taking on a student intern or apprentice which would cover things like resources required for internship supervision and mentorship. Alternatively, we could look at tax incentives for companies who sign up to participate in specific internship programmes. Such incentive schemes are implemented in countries, such as the United States and Canada, for businesses to offer high-quality work experience programmes for students. In Singapore, we have similar schemes in place as well, such as the SME Talent Programme for SMEs. We should review such existing schemes and assess how to expand and enhance them to bring a larger number of students and companies into the fold.

Madam, in conclusion, I am glad to support the recommendations by ASPIRE. It shows commitment to equip students, regardless of their background or chosen path, with the right skills and experiences to empower them to take charge of their careers and plot their path to success. However, the tough part will now come in making firm commitments and dedicating the resources required to making these recommendations a reality. With that, Madam, I support the Motion.

3.25 pm

The Senior Minister of State, Prime Minister's Office (Mr Heng Chee How): Mdm Speaker, thank you very much for allowing me to join this debate. I fully support the recommendations of the ASPIRE Committee's report and the Motion before us.

To the Labour Movement, a better future for Singaporeans must include good prospects for Singaporeans to get good jobs and to enjoy an improving standard of living. And for that to happen, good jobs must be created in the first place in Singapore, and then Singaporeans must have the aptitudes and competencies needed to take on those good jobs.

Indeed, the two are inter-linked. If companies find that Singaporeans do not have the competencies needed for the better jobs that they intend to create – and here it applies to companies both big and small, MNCs and SMEs – then they find less reason to create those jobs in Singapore or to bring those better jobs into Singapore. So, the ability and the availability of skilled manpower and talent are very critical to ensuring the availability and the creation of good jobs in Singapore and that better future for Singaporean workers and Singaporeans.

Should that be a worry for us? Could there possibly, potentially, be not enough Singaporeans with relevant competencies to attract or to undertake and to anchor these better jobs for the future?

I think it is possible and I can think of a number of possibilities of why that might happen.

One challenge would be our small population and our low fertility. There may be a constraint in sheer lack of numbers, though, to some extent, progress in our efforts to improve job design, value-add and total productivity will help to ameliorate the challenge.

But for the students that we do have, there could also be challenges because students could be studying courses that mismatch with industry needs, or because the industry needs change and their catch-up process in terms of what is being taught to the students is not quick enough.

Students may also choose to work in industries that need competencies that are totally different from their course of study. So, they study in one thing but they choose to work in a different line. All that investment does not convert into value.

Companies also may be part of the problem because some companies may not be able to retain the workers by providing challenging work, competitive rewards or attractive prospects. So, even if they have the right students coming to work for them, they do not keep them long enough. And, again, they lose the experience.

In other words, if we are already short of people, we really, as a country, cannot afford to waste anyone, waste the talent or the skill, through any sub-optimal matching of training and work requirements, or through the premature loss of talent and skilled personnel.

It is, therefore, imperative that we "Teach Right, Learn Right, Work Right and Reward Right". I believe that if we do these four things right, we will then put ourselves on a virtuous cycle of skills building, value creation, good rewards and, eventually, ever improving living standards.

In this regard, I welcome and support the recommendations of the ASPIRE Committee as they seek to strengthen our ability to cut waste and maximise value with respect to students studying and working in relevant and related areas.

I think that for the full value of the ASPIRE report to be realised, we must focus on three critical points.

The first one is the link between "Teach Right" and "Learn Right". This is about ensuring that courses of study being offered are themselves valuable and relevant to current and emerging industry needs, and also in helping students choose the right course of study that best fits their talent, their aspirations and their abilities.

This is conceptually easy to understand, but it is actually not easy to put into practice correctly and continuously because there are many different parts that are moving. To articulate them and to synchronise them will be challenging. But it is a very important part for this enhanced capability to link between the ITE, the Polytechnics on the one hand, and industry on the other, in order for both sides to better understand the job requirements and the job opportunities, and also the training that must be put in place to link the two. This must be properly resourced and carefully built up.

The second link is that between "Learn Right" and "Work Right". This part concerns the workplace. In today's reality, lifelong learning and lifelong updating of knowledge and skills are not just nice add-ons for those people with extraordinary aspirations. In fact, it is a basic action: for all workers, in order to preserve employability for themselves; and for companies, in order to preserve their competitiveness.

The better Singapore is at ensuring updating and relevance of skills, the more resilient and attractive our workforce and economy would be for the future. This is precisely why the Labour Movement is very keen. This is at the core of the future of our workers.

Thus, it is vital that substantial attention be paid to, and significant investments be made in Continuing Education and Training (CET). An ideal CET system would be one with strong institutions and service providers within itself, that these providers are able to train, upgrade, retrain and match and rematch workers efficiently into good and well-fitting jobs. It must also be one that interacts actively with education institutions in a two-way loop to mutually update and upgrade on needs and capability-building. When that happens consistently and pervasively, then the investments of time, effort and money that each person and the country put into pre-employment education will yield a longer stream of good returns throughout a person's working years and will not be wasted mid-stream.

In this regard, the Labour Movement fully supports the proposed improvement to ITEs and Polytechnics in strengthening the industrial link through purpose-focused internships and Place-and-Train programmes. We also support the enhancement in the capability to provide more accurate and timely job-market information and also job counselling.

I would just like to also quote an example with regard to how companies and the education institutions can work closely together in order to make this happen. Here, I quote the example of Rolls-Royce. First, education and work should not be seen as separate and compartmentalised passages of life. Often, when students reach their graduation year, they are uncertain of which sector to go into, what job to take and where their decisions will lead them. Some find that their course of study does not open the doors to their dream job. Others simply take on the job that offers the highest starting pay, and many subsequently job-hop without clear career objectives.

Education, training and Career Guidance, or ECG, is, therefore, important to help individuals make well-informed decisions about their education, training and career choices right from the start. ECG needs to start from young and extend all the way to working adults. And it has to be tailored to different needs. For young students, ECG aims to help them explore different areas to figure out their interests and strengths early on, and provide them with a clearer idea on the wide range of education options available. For tertiary students, it is about preparing them to enter the workforce, and helping them explore the types of careers that they wish to go into. For working adults, ECG can help serve as a stocktake and enable them to explore learning opportunities to further build up their skills, or retrain in another field should they wish to switch careers.

In support of ASPIRE's recommendations, MOE recently announced that they will provide more resources to enhance ECG in Primary and Secondary schools, Polytechnics and ITE, through providing trained ECG officers and a new ECG programme.

WDA will be developing an online integrated national ECG portal that will be used to deliver ECG to students starting from Secondary schools and throughout a Singaporean's career. In developing this integrated ECG framework, WDA will work closely with MOE and other relevant stakeholders to ensure that efforts will be coordinated across schools, post-Secondary education institutions and WDA's career centres.

Next, WDA will support more employer-driven, workplace-based training, such as Place-and-Train programmes. Not only will these facilitate the transition from school to work, working and learning in real-world environments will enable fresh graduates to apply and deepen their skills, as many in this House have alluded to, in the areas that they were trained for. It also provides an additional option for Polytechnic and ITE graduates to attain industry-recognised skill certifications.

Take Ms Ong Teng Teng, for example. Ms Ong enrolled herself in WDA's Place-and-Train programme for Enrolled Nurses in April 2008 and embarked on a fast-track journey into the nursing profession.

After an 18-month training at ITE College East, with course fees and monthly training allowances co-sponsored by WDA and her employer, Ang Mo Kio–Thye Hua Kwan Hospital, she quickly built up a strong foundation in nursing and worked as an Enrolled Nurse at the hospital. Within four years, she was promoted to Staff Nurse and has continued to pursue skills upgrading by earning her diploma in Nursing at NYP.

With the strong support from her employer and mentorship from Prof Edward Poon, Ms Ong emerged as the top graduate of her cohort and received multiple awards, including the Tay Eng Soon Award which recognises ITE graduates who achieve exceptional results for further studies at a Polytechnic. And she does not intend to stop there. To further enhance her skills, Ms Ong is intending to pursue a degree in Nursing.

Indeed, this example reflects what ASPIRE is and is not. ASPIRE is certainly not cause for degree-bashing. It does not aim to discourage upgrading to degrees, but it does encourage people to find out their interests and strengths before choosing to deepen their skills via the vocational or academic route, or both.

In fact, if an individual has found his niche and would like to continually upgrade and eventually pursue a degree which industry recognises, then this is what we should encourage, as opposed to the mentality that "getting any degree is better than no degree".

We will extend WDA's existing Place-and-Train programmes for working adults like Ms Ong to Polytechnic and ITE graduates via the new ASPIRE Place-and-Train programmes. WDA will continue to provide matching of Polytechnic and ITE graduates to progressive employers who are committed to support the graduates in contextualising what they have learnt and deepen their skills through on-the-job learning and further upgrading through multiple pathways.

To ensure industry relevance, the Place-and-Train programmes at Polytechnics and ITEs will be developed in collaboration with industry, and we have identified sectors to pilot this programme from 2016. These range from Biologics to Logistics in the Polytechnics, and Marine & Offshore Engineering to Pastry & Baking in ITE. WDA will share more details on these programmes as and when they are ready.

Moving forward, we are reviewing our CET Masterplan to improve the quality and effectiveness of our CET system in anticipation of future challenges and uncertainties. WDA will also work with our tripartite partners to develop the sectoral competency frameworks under ASPIRE that all stakeholders can make reference to. More details will be announced.

Even as we are having this debate about ASPIRE's recommendations, yesterday evening, a young diploma graduate came to see me with his mother at my Meet-the-People session. He asked me to appeal for a study loan for him to take an external degree with a private educational institution as his family was financially strapped. I asked him if he would consider working first, to apply his skills acquired during his diploma, and pursue a degree later. But he told me very decisively that he wants to complete all his studies before starting work!

Certainly, this shows that a cultural change in society's attitudes towards paper qualifications that ASPIRE calls for will not take place overnight and will require a whole-of-society effort. As several Members of this House, such as Ms Denise Phua, Mr Zaqy Mohamad and Mr K Karthikeyan, spoke about yesterday, we require all hands on deck to help every Singaporean maximise their potential and achieve their aspirations for better wages, better jobs and a better future through multiple pathways. With this, Madam, I support the Motion.

Mr Zainal Sapari (Pasir Ris-Punggol): Mdm Speaker, in the spirit of Bulan Bahasa, please allow me to address in Malay.

(In Malay): [Please refer to Vernacular Speech.] I support the recommendations of the Applied Study in Polytechnics and Institute of Technical Education Review (ASPIRE) Committee because these recommendations can potentially help Polytechnic and ITE graduates to upgrade their skills and productivity, which can provide better opportunities for them in terms of their career and income.

NTUC welcomes the recommendation to strengthen the Education and Career Guidance (ECG) programme in schools, ITEs and Polytechnics. In order to ensure that good guidance is provided, it is essential that the staff that are selected to run this programme are very knowledgeable and able to give sound advice. On this matter, I would like to suggest that MOE provide job opportunities to mature or aged workers who have long careers in certain fields and have a rich working experience and knowledge. These experienced workers can be trained to become counsellors who can give guidance to help students make good academic and career choices.

I would also like to urge MOE to encourage schools, Polytechnics and ITEs to work with the Labour Movement through nEbO, an NTUC branch that comprises union members who are youths. nEbO is spelt with a small "n" and "b" and capital "E" and "O". Unofficially, it means "nobody enjoys being ordinary". Presently, NTUC's nEbO is collaborating with 11 Secondary schools, ITEs and Polytechnics to organise study visits for students so that they can see and understand the careers that they are interested in. I hope that every Secondary and tertiary student will become a nEbO member in the future, so that the Labour Movement, through the unions, can help them explore their interest in their career of choice.

ASPIRE also recommended the enhancement of the internship programme for Polytechnic and ITE students. Here, I hope that these students will be equipped with knowledge on the Employment Act. This is important to ensure that they know their rights as workers even during their internship. On this matter, too, NTUC is willing to play a part to enhance the students' awareness and knowledge about the Employment Act and the role that the unions can play to help them in terms of their employment and standard of living.

ASPIRE also proposed to assist the deepening of skills after completing ITE and Polytechnic education. I think that this effort will achieve good results if MOE collaborates with organisations that possess the capabilities and have been providing career counselling services. The Employment and Employability Institute, or e2i, the Lifelong Learning Institute and WDA have a group of career consultants that are willing to help Polytechnic and ITE students choose the right career and can continue to help them enhance their work skills in the future. The expert resources available in these organisations must be utilised to achieve ASPIRE's goals.

On the recommendation to develop sector-specific skills and progression frameworks with the cooperation of the industries, the Labour Movement would like to urge MOE and MOM to involve NTUC in this effort because NTUC is actively encouraging every sector to adopt a progressive wage model that provides wage increment ladders that are based on productivity, skills and career. Any framework that is developed must be transparent and fair so that it will motivate workers to upgrade their skills and productivity. For this framework to achieve the intended objectives, it is important that emphasis is given to the role and responsibility of the employer to ensure that the worker's career is based on his/her skills, productivity and responsibilities, and not solely on educational qualifications.

ASPIRE can transform the labour force in Singapore because it presents a good future for workers who are ITE and Polytechnic graduates by enhancing the opportunity to upgrade skills that are relevant to their careers. Even so, it is important also to make efforts to change mindsets and convince the community that success in the workplace does not necessarily depend on an undergraduate degree. Success can also be achieved by deepening skills in the jobs that we are interested in.

In this aspect, I would like to urge Mendaki and other Malay/Muslim organisations to work with MOE to lead the effort in engaging Malay/Muslim parents and students on ASPIRE. Allow me to quote a phrase from the Suara Musyawarah report, "The committee is concerned that although many education pathways are provided to the community, the parents and the students themselves may not even be aware of the career objectives and potential that may be present with each choice." Therefore, it is imperative that our community becomes aware of the efforts that will be taken to implement ASPIRE's recommendations, and we must make use of the available opportunities to help Malay students in the ITEs and Polytechnics to understand and achieve success in their careers.

This effort to engage the Malay/Muslim community will also be in line with the Suara Musyawarah committee's recommendations to have a more specific public awareness programme on educational and career pathways. This may bring about a mindset shift among parents and students about ITE and Polytechnic graduates, since this group of students will possess niche skills and expertise that can be upgraded so that they can enjoy good careers.

However, the Suara Musyawarah committee admits that the Malay/Muslim community is facing the challenge to stay competitive within Singapore's labour force. According to the Suara Musyawarah report, "The inability or the refusal to upskill is usually linked to issues of finance and the readiness to do so, family commitments and possible disruptions to the present careers." These are issues that may hinder the Malay/Muslim community from getting the benefits, in terms of career, that can be gained from the implementation of ASPIRE's recommendations. Hence, emphasis should continue to be given to mindset change, skills upgrading and learning within the Malay/Muslim community through the efforts of MENDAKI and other Malay/Muslim organisations.

Mdm Speaker, before I end, allow me to read a poem from the Suara Musyawarah report:

Lightning flashes across the sky

Dark, grey clouds ahanging up on high

Whilst awalking and thinking of policies

To stabilise and strengthen the community.

Allow me to also reply to that poem to show my support to our Malay language:

Never stand on open ground

When rain and thunder are around

Opportunities are right in front of our eyes

And ASPIRE can give hope to our community.

Mdm Speaker, I support the Motion.

Mr Ang Wei Neng (Jurong): Mdm Speaker, I speak in support of the Motion. When Prime Minister spoke about the recommendations of ASPIRE and played down the importance of getting a degree during this year's National Day Rally, it was met with strong support as well as scepticism.

Strong support because many of us know that getting a degree is not an end all and be all approach to improving one's career prospects. During one of my weekly house visits, I met a couple in their 50s. There was a huge family portrait on the wall showing three of their children wearing mortarboards. I commented that it was great for their children to be graduates. The mother of three replied, "文凭不值钱" or "the degrees are no more valuable". I asked them why and they explained that their children's salary did not improve significantly after obtaining their degrees from the private Universities. This is similar to the story narrated by Mr Heng earlier on.

Singaporeans, as with their counterparts in other Asian societies, would not hesitate to invest heavily in education. In the struggle to be educated, the pinnacle is the attainment of a University degree. That is why in Taiwan, with a population of slightly more than 23 million people, there are 163 universities. That is seven universities for every one million people. In South Korea, with a population of about 50 million, there are 411 universities or eight universities per million people. How about Singapore?

When I check a website for the list of Universities in Singapore, I am surprised to learn that there are 30 Universities. Besides the six public Universities, the rest are mainly private Universities, and many of which I come across for the first time. Thirty Universities for a population of five million people in Singapore, it works out to be about six Universities for every one million people, not too far away from Korea and Taiwan. Certainly, we have to count the enrolment figures for each of the Universities so as to make a fair comparison across the different countries, but the number of Universities could still serve as a good proxy.

Is having too many private Universities a problem? At least Taiwan admitted so. The unemployment rate among the Taiwan graduates is high. One in five recent young graduates in Taiwan could not find a job within one year of graduation. Thus, Taiwan is taking steps to reduce the number of universities from 160 to about 110.

Similarly, in Singapore, we need to guard against the mushrooming of private Universities resulting in the mass proliferation of University graduates, compromising the quality of the graduates' training and lowering the value of the degree. This is especially so as we extend the university space in the public Universities. While we wait for the recommendations of ASPIRE to take effect, I urge MOE to take stock of our private Universities, tighten the academic standard, enhance the system to differentiate the better ones so that Singaporeans could obtain better value from these private Universities. We need to persuade Singaporeans not to spend excessive money to obtain a degree that does not add much value, and this is why the ASPIRE's report is timely.

However, what is even more important is how the ASPIRE's recommendations are implemented. As indicated by many speakers before me, the Civil Service needs to take a lead in making the changes.

When I started my career in the Police Force more than 20 years ago, I realised that there was a clear demarcation of career paths for diploma holders, normal graduates and overseas scholars. Their career paths hardly crossed. For example, non-graduates started off as Junior Police Officers and it would take years or even decades for them to be promoted to the rank of Inspector, the lowest of the rank of senior officers. Returned overseas scholars receive higher pay even if they are of the same rank as the local graduates, regardless of their performance. I must say that most overseas scholars generally perform much better than the other graduates. However, there are some who do not perform as well and that sours the feelings of the majority of the Police officers. I understand that similar situations occur in the Army and many other Government departments. It is probably a lot better off today as compared to two decades ago but there is still room for improvement, particularly to allow civil servants with different qualifications to compete on a more even ground.

It does not take too long for a non-graduate officer to see where the goal post lies after the annual promotion exercise. On the ground, people use the term "farmer" to indicate civil servants who do not have a degree or scholarship. For ASPIRE's recommendations to be effectively implemented, the perception that "once a farmer always a farmer" in the Civil Service has to be demolished; otherwise, many will remain skeptical about ASPIRE's good intention.

I am, therefore, heartened to hear Prime Minister Lee announcing a review on the human resource policy within the Civil Service. The Civil Service, as the biggest employer, needs to take the lead in walking the talk if we want to tell Singaporeans that there are other routes besides the University degree route to get ahead in one's career.

In summary, I applaud the effort to change the mindset that "obtaining a degree is the only ticket to a better career". However, we need to be mindful that the change process takes time and MOE needs to do more to improve the quality of the courses offered by the private universities in Singapore. Last but not least, the Civil Service needs to take the lead to even the playing field for officers with different qualifications.

6.26 pm

Mr David Ong (Jurong): Mdm Speaker, I rise in support of the Motion as it is both timely and a step in the right direction.

A fundamental tenet underlying the Committee's approach was that all Singaporeans should have opportunities to realise their full potential and progress in life, regardless of their starting point. Many Members of this House have spoken about this and I, too, strongly support this key tenet. Indeed, we must make available to as many people as possible multiple routes to a successful and fulfilling life and career rather than solely based on paper qualifications.

In a young and developing country like Singapore, it is important that every citizen is developed to the best of his or her ability and, as far as possible, every citizen should be helped to achieve a position where he can best contribute to society and also find the most fulfilment. As such, this message, that opportunities will be given to all, regardless of academic qualifications, needs to be disseminated to all strata of our society, all stakeholders, employers, employees, students as well as parents.

I think the central factor to this exercise is how our country and we, as a people, define and celebrate success, and also how we treat and value people and respect every job. It seems naturally ingrained in us that we want to do well and to hope that our children can be successful. Like all parents, we are hopeful that the next generation will do better than the one before. But how do we define what is "better" or "successful"?

Meritocracy is an essential and integral part of Singapore's political and social culture for years and academic qualification is often viewed as a stepping stone to getting a secured future, grounded in a good job with better pay. This emphasis on paper qualifications, or worse, the idea that a degree of any type is needed for future success, has permeated parts of our society.

In the minds of some, this has mutated into a sense of entitlement, where there is a belief that once a person has a degree, regardless of what one wants to do, that person should be given a job with pay commensurate to the degree. I must reiterate that I am not at all saying that degrees are no longer valuable or worth pursuing. Rather, it is the pursuit for degrees sake, regardless of its relevance to the worker or his job that needs validating. Big changes in mindsets will be called for if this mental shift is to be practicable.

Whilst meritocracy has transformed our country from Third to First world in a short span of 49 years and benefited Singapore and its citizens, it can be argued that the time has come for us to relook this primary "key" which unlocks the doors to opportunities. Can there not be other alternative keys which may also unlock those same doors? Or perhaps the issue can be seen in another way, where the idea of "meritocracy" is not equated or so closely intertwined with "academic achievements", such that other forms of achievement can also be recognised on equal footing as "meritocracy"? I submit that such non-academic achievement must include work skills, experience, or even recognised knowledge acquired possibly in ways not linked to examinations or written tests. In essence, we must strive for a fair meritocracy to ensure that equal opportunities will benefit all segments of our society.

Singapore has been successful in its economic restructuring since 1965, due largely in part to its ability to establish a close relationship between policies for skills formation and the demand for skills at each base of the country's economic growth.

One of Singapore's great achievements in education is an early emphasis on technical training to develop a workforce that is continually relevant and employable. Singapore's ability to anticipate and adapt to changing trends and employment landscape has been critical in future-proofing our workforce.

The ASPIRE report is not just about providing more opportunities for Polytechnic and ITE students to progress but also our continual effort to anticipate and make our workforce future-ready. The post-European crisis has churned out some valuable lessons for Singapore. Germany's successful model of apprenticeship has spared the country from the worst of Europe's crisis.

Whilst our younger new job entrants as well as some existing employees would be happy with the prospect of careers tied less to a paper qualifications but more to their applied skills and job performance, one cannot underestimate the width and breadth of change that is needed. While the efforts of the ASPIRE Committee are commendable as well as the Government's willingness to accept all the recommendations, it is one thing to have these fine recommendations but another if the practices on the ground are not in sync.

Society's mindsets and cultural changes are needed for ASPIRE and the new employment culture to achieve its intended objective. For the recommendations of ASPIRE to be successful, much work is needed to boost recruitment and recognition of apprenticeship programmes. People must believe that apprenticeships are viable and worthwhile options for them to have a sustained and fulfilling career.

Employers must also adopt a holistic approach in the development of their workers. Employees can be placed in jobs that could enable them to hone deep skills and provide scope for developing their career growth and progression. Employers can better outreach to employees with succinct communication of the company's training and development framework.

The Building and Construction Authority Apprenticeship programmes introduced since 2012 not only help firms to upgrade their existing local tradesmen, the programmes also offer vocational pathway to an academic route. Most importantly, upon completion of these programmes, the apprentices will qualify to be registered as Core Trade tradesmen or foremen. Such recognition for their trade specialisation is critical in the success of the Apprenticeship programme.

Parents are naturally anxious about their children's future and may seek assurance that indeed without a degree, their children can progress and be recognised at their work place. The task forward will take time to generate the buy-in. With the resolve of the Tripartite Committee led by Deputy Prime Minister Tharman to give weight and to drive the process forward, I look forward to more industry partners and employers adopting a structured apprenticeship model where Polytechnic and ITE students, who have demonstrated their ability to combine academic and work skills, are the kind of workers for the new economy.

Let me share a case in point of Germany's experience as compared to the United States' dual focus on preventing students from dropping out and getting them into universities. Under the Pell Grant Program, it costs the American taxpayers more than US$30 billion each year and yet American students periodically do not do as well comparatively. On the other hand, Germany's vocation trainings are based on the enlightened view that not everyone will benefit from a university education. The expensive resources can be better allocated elsewhere. A notable success story of Germany's new belief system is the famous chef, Claus-Peter Lumpp.

Chef Lumpp's story could just be one of the many who drop out of schools in our mainstream education. His mother gave him permission to leave school, but only if he found an apprenticeship. Lumpp landed one in the kitchen of the Hotel Bareiss in 1982. Today, Lumpp's Restaurant Bareiss has a three-star rating from the prestigious Michelin guide and most of the chefs in his kitchen were mentored under the same system that brought his talents to the fore. As a result of this system, few Germans find themselves unemployable. The youth unemployment rate, for example, was just 7.7% in February, well below that of the US and the euro zone as a whole at 23.9%.

In this regard, Mdm Speaker, our employers need to play their part to give priority in nurturing deep skills and developing the potential of our workers. Many other countries are strait-jacketed in their policies, with many young people with general degrees who have the expectation that they would obtain lofty professional jobs commensurate with their qualifications. We need to stay away from such gridlock. In some of these same countries, workers with essential skills were able to get ahead in life with better pay and career prospects.

Mdm Speaker, our world is fast changing. We are now faced with the rapid rise of smart machines and systems, emergence of new media ecology, super-structured organisations, a globally connected world and an ageing population. These disruptive drivers are reshaping the future landscape for our workforce. With a rapidly ageing population, coupled with the fast changing outlook of the modern workplace, workers in the future will also need to be adaptable lifelong learners.

Many senior workers may have wanted to pursue a certificate, diploma or degree when they were younger but were unable due to financial constraints or family obligations. Employers and our educational institutions can also look at welcoming our senior workforce to pursue their passion for lifelong learning to gain knowledge and expand their horizons in their field of interests.

This June, I had the pleasure of attending the ITE College Central Graduation Ceremony. I would like to make mention of a special graduand, Ms Liaw Lay Kian. Lay Kian is a NITEC in Nursing graduate who enrolled for her NITEC at age 50 and graduated this year at age 52 which is three times the age of most her graduating cohort. She could not pursue her studies earlier as she had to care for her bed-bound father-in-law for 16 years and her ailing husband for 10 months before he passed away. Lay Kian has intimate and first-hand knowledge of the toll illness can take on the family and can empathise with the patients and their families' struggles.

She brought her passion in palliative care to Dover Park Hospice as a volunteer and then enrolled into a Nursing course at ITE. At 50 years, she found it daunting to go back to school but her determination and resilience saw her achieving an almost perfect GPA of 3.94 which earned her the Tay Eng Soon Gold Medal. She currently works at Dover Park Hospice and will be pursuing a Diploma in Nursing course starting this October. Lay Kian demonstrates an inspiring sense of determination and resilience. This quality is more important than any paper qualifications. At her age, she continued to pursue lifelong learning even when it was difficult. Learning new skills when one has gone past the conventional school-going age is never easy, but Lay Kian has shown us that personal determination and resilience can make it possible.

In closing, let us not allow any lack of paper qualifications, even age, be barriers to have a fulfilling and rewarding career. Older workers can aspire too and should be given equal opportunities. I urge employers, parents and education institutions to come together and value our precious human talents regardless of their starting points. Let us re-define "success" and embrace a fair meritocracy that will uplift all segments of our society, providing each with equal opportunities and many pathways to achieve their own aspirations. Indeed, we are not scaling to reach a single summit but enabling all of us to reach the many different peaks of a wide mountain range. Madam, with this, I support the Motion.
